prefix: Approach the following question the way someone in high school would.
problem_prompt:
Approach the following question the way someone in high school would. Find the modular inverse of $27$, modulo $28$.

Express your answer as an integer from $0$ to $27$, inclusive.
solution:
We are looking for an integer $a$ such that $27a$ is congruent to 1 modulo 28. In other words, we want to solve  \[
27 a \equiv 1 \pmod{28}.
\]We subtract $28a$ from the left-hand side to obtain $-a\equiv 1 \pmod{28}$. This congruence is equivalent to the previous one since $28a$ is a multiple of 28. Next we multiply both sides by $-1$ to obtain $a\equiv -1\pmod{28}$. Thus $28-1=\boxed{27}$ is the modular inverse of 27 (mod 28). (Note that since $(m-1)^2=m^2-2m+1\equiv 1\pmod{m}$, we always have that $m-1$ is its own inverse modulo $m$.)
gpt_response:
To find the modular inverse of $27$ modulo $28$, we need to find an integer $x$ such that $27x \equiv 1 \pmod{28}$.

We can start by checking multiples of $27$ until we find one that leaves a remainder of $1$ when divided by $28$:

$27(1) = 27 \equiv -1 \pmod{28}$
$27(2) = 54 \equiv 26 \pmod{28}$
$27(3) = 81 \equiv 25 \pmod{28}$
$27(4) = 108 \equiv 24 \pmod{28}$
$27(5) = 135 \equiv 23 \pmod{28}$
$27(6) = 162 \equiv 22 \pmod{28}$
$27(7) = 189 \equiv 21 \pmod{28}$
$27(8) = 216 \equiv 20 \pmod{28}$
$27(9) = 243 \equiv 19 \pmod{28}$
$27(10) = 270 \equiv 18 \pmod{28}$
$27(11) = 297 \equiv 17 \pmod{28}$
$27(12) = 324 \equiv 16 \pmod{28}$
$27(13) = 351 \equiv 15 \pmod{28}$
$27(14) = 378 \equiv 14 \pmod{28}$
$27(15) = 405 \equiv 13 \pmod{28}$
$27(16) = 432 \equiv 12 \pmod{28}$
$27(17) = 459 \equiv 11 \pmod{28}$
$27(18) = 486 \equiv 10 \pmod{28}$
$27(19) = 513 \equiv 9 \pmod{28}$
$27(20) = 540 \equiv 8 \pmod{28}$
$27(21) = 567 \equiv 7 \pmod{28}$
$27(22) = 594 \equiv 6 \pmod{28}$
$27(23) = 621 \equiv 5 \pmod{28}$
$27(24) = 648 \equiv 4 \pmod{28}$
$27(25) = 675 \equiv 3 \pmod{28}$
$27(26) = 702 \equiv 2 \pmod{28}$
$27(27) = 729 \equiv 1 \pmod{28}$

So, the modular inverse of $27$ modulo $28$ is $27$.
